TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit ControlDesigner extends System.Web.UI.Design.HtmlControlDesigner

Docs.summary: Provides a base control designer class for extending the design-mode behavior of a Web server control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class provides a base control designer class that can be inherited from and extended to provide design-time support for a Web server control in a design host, such as [!INCLUDE[vsprvslong](~/includes/vsprvslong-md.md)].
The object model for working with design-time rendering is improved over earlier versions, with the following new base classes to provide access to the simplified object model:
- <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner>, which is not new, but has been greatly improved.
- <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ContainerControlDesigner>.
- <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.CompositeControlDesigner>.
## Automatic Formatting You can create a variety of automatic and pre-defined formats that can simplify the process of page developers who are applying complex style changes to custom Web server controls. For example, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.TableDesigner> control, which derives from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class, provides many automatic formats from which to choose. To implement and provide automatic formatting in your custom controls, use the following features:
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.AutoFormats%2A> property.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnAutoFormatApplied%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerAutoFormat> class.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerAutoFormatStyle> class.
## Action Lists (Smart Tags) Action lists are menus of important or widely used tasks that a page developer who uses a control can perform in a design-time user interface (UI), such as [!INCLUDE[vsprvslong](~/includes/vsprvslong-md.md)]. For example, the design-time view of your control could provide a menu of available tasks. This includes a task to format the control automatically. To learn about action lists, start with the following features:
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ActionLists%2A> property.
- The <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionList> class.
- The <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionList.GetSortedActionItems%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionListCollection> class.
- The <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionMethodItem> class.
- The <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionPropertyItem> class.
## Control Designer Regions Regions are editable areas in the design-time view of a Web server control. This feature offers WYSIWYG-like editing of the template content, inner controls, and properties at design time. You can have the control designer create controls in regions or you can use the Toolbox to drag and drop controls into regions. Regions are managed with the following features:
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnClick%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion> class.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.EditableDesignerRegion> class.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetEditableDesignerRegionContent%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetEditableDesignerRegionContent%2A> method.
## Templates The model for creating a UI for design-time editing of templated controls, such as the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control, has been greatly improved from earlier versions. You can create complex custom controls that include templates for various parts of the control, and your custom control designer can help page developers who are modifying templates with the following features:
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.TemplateGroups%2A> property.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.InTemplateMode%2A> property.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.TemplateGroup> class.
## Design-Time Rendering The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class has the following methods to support design-time rendering of the Web server control. Most of these methods are the same as in earlier versions:
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetEmptyDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetErrorDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UpdateDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.CreatePlaceHolderDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to create a simple designer class that derives from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class. This control designer supports a custom `TextControl` class and provides a command to change the text size of a control at design time. The control designer is associated with the control by specifying the control designer in a <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerAttribute> object declaration on the `TextControl` class. The key to persisting property changes from the control designer to the HTML markup is found in the `ToggleTextSize` method of the custom `ActionList` class.
To try the example, add a reference to the System.Design.dll assembly and compile the code.
[!code-csharp[ControlDesignerSample#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/ControlDesignerSample/cs/TextControlDesigner.cs#1)] [!code-vb[ControlDesignerSample#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/ControlDesignerSample/vb/TextControlDesigner.vb#1)] [!code-aspx-csharp[ControlDesignerSample#8](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/ControlDesignerSample/cs/TextControlDesigner.aspx#8)] [!code-aspx-vb[ControlDesignerSample#8](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/ControlDesignerSample/vb/TextControlDesigner.aspx#8)]

## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to create a simple composite control with a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Label> and a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TextBox> control, together with properties to set the Text properties on both internal controls, and also the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.Width%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.BackColor%2A> properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TextBox> control. An associated control designer class creates three <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionMethodItem> commands, each of which sets two properties on the control, and can be rolled back with the undo functionality of the design host.
[!code-csharp[DesignerInvokeTransactedChange#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/DesignerInvokeTransactedChange/CS/InvokeTransactedChangeSample.cs#1)] [!code-vb[DesignerInvokeTransactedChange#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/DesignerInvokeTransactedChange/VB/InvokeTransactedChangeSample.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: Public Overridable ReadOnly Property AutoFormats As DesignerAutoFormatCollection

Docs.summary: Gets the collection of predefined automatic formatting schemes to display in the **Auto Format** dialog box for the associated control at design time.
Docs.value: A object that contains the predefined schemes for the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A complete Web server control includes not only the control, but also, possibly, a corresponding control designer class that is derived from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class and a formatting class that is derived from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerAutoFormat> class. The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.AutoFormats%2A> property is a collection of instances of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerAutoFormat> class. For a working example of automatic formatting in [!INCLUDE[vsprvslong](~/includes/vsprvslong-md.md)], see <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Calendar>.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to implement the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.AutoFormats%2A> property in a custom control designer. The derived control designer implements the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.AutoFormats%2A> property by adding three instances of a custom automatic format that are derived from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerAutoFormat> class.
[!code-csharp[DesignerAutoFormat#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/DesignerAutoFormat/CS/DesignerAutoFormat.cs#1)] [!code-vb[DesignerAutoFormat#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/DesignerAutoFormat/VB/DesignerAutoFormat.vb#1)]

block.para: Controls that automatically expose AutoFormats get a task list and context commands for their formats. When you are using automatic formats, use the property to set the properties in your callback function.

Docs.param: The error message to include in the generated HTML markup.
Docs.summary: Creates HTML markup to display a specified error message at design time.
Docs.returns: An HTML markup string that contains the specified error message.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.CreateErrorDesignTimeHtml%2A> method to create HTML markup to display an error message for a control at design time. The value for `errorMessage` specifies a localized string that is displayed to the user of the control at design time.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class implementation of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.CreateErrorDesignTimeHtml%2A> method returns a table with two rows, as follows:
- The first row contains the type name and site name for the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentDesigner.Component%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> object.
- The second row contains the input error message string.
To generate HTML markup for an error message with an associated exception, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.CreateErrorDesignTimeHtml%28System.String%2CSystem.Exception%29> overload. To generate HTML markup for an exception without specifying a localized error message, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetErrorDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.

block.para: The overload is functionally equivalent to calling the method with e set to .

The exception to include in the generated HTML string.
Docs.summary: Creates the HTML markup to display a specified exception error message at design time.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.CreateErrorDesignTimeHtml%2A> method to provide simple HTML markup that can be used to display error and exception details for a control at design time. The value for `errorMessage` specifies a localized string that is displayed to the user of the control at design time.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class implementation of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.CreateErrorDesignTimeHtml%2A> method returns a table with two rows, as follows:
- The first row contains the type name and site name for the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentDesigner.Component%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> object.
- The second row contains the input error message and the <xref:System.Exception.Message%2A> string of the exception.
To generate HTML markup for an error message without specifying an exception, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.CreateErrorDesignTimeHtml%28System.String%29> overload. To generate HTML markup for an exception without specifying a localized error message, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetErrorDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.

block.para: The method should be called from the or method when exceptions occur.

Docs.summary: Provides a simple rectangular placeholder representation that displays the type and ID of the control.

block.para: The typical design pattern is to try to get HTML markup through the associated control, and then if an error is encountered, call the method. If no markup is returned by the control, call the method, which if it is not overridden to provide specific markup, calls the method, which should contain information about the type and ID of the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The design host calls the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method to get the design-time HTML markup and the current list of control designer regions. Using the DesignerRegionCollection, the design host can then request the markup for each editable control designer region.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method is provided for a derived control designer, such as the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.GridViewDesigner> class, that must process the content for the region before calling the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
## Examples The following code example shows how to create HTML markup using the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegionCollection> collection.

Docs.param: An object that can retrieve global and local services.
Docs.summary: Returns an appropriate resource provider factory, depending on the globalization settings in the configuration file for the site.
Docs.returns: A object, if any are defined in the configuration file; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks A resource provider factory creates resource providers and resource writers, depending on the current settings in the system.web/globalization section of the configuration file (either the Machine.config or Web.config files for both global and local resources). If no globalization settings are found, the `serviceProvider` parameter is used to create a <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignTimeResourceProviderFactory> object using the default implementation for the design host.
Typically, control developers will not override the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeResourceProviderFactory%2A> method.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetEmptyDesignTimeHtml%2A> method should be called in the implementation of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method when there is no design-time HTML markup.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to override the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method in a custom control designer. If the `Text` property for the associated control is empty, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method calls <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetEmptyDesignTimeHtml%2A> method. Otherwise, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method creates and renders a `Hyperlink` control.

## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetErrorDesignTimeHtml%2A> method is typically called, if an exception is thrown in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to generate design-time HTML markup for the control when an error occurs and call the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.CreatePlaceHolderDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
[!code-csharp[System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.LoginDesigner#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.LoginDesigner/CS/LoginDesigner.cs#2)] [!code-vb[System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.LoginDesigner#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.LoginDesigner/VB/LoginDesigner.vb#2)]

block.para: The typical design pattern is to try to get HTML markup through the associated control, and then if an error is encountered, call the method. If no markup is returned by the control, call the method, which if it is not overridden to provide specific markup, calls the method, which should contain information about the type and ID of the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.Initialize%2A> method is called by the design host to complete the following actions:
- Load the control designer with the component to design.
- Set up the view on the control using the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetViewFlags%2A> method.
- Verify that the associated control is of the right type.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use a control class and a control designer class that override the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.Initialize%2A> method to initialize internal variables.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A Web server control is in template mode when a read-only template is currently being viewed or an editable template is being edited in a design host such as [!INCLUDE[vsprvslong](~/includes/vsprvslong-md.md)].
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class supplies a default <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ViewEventHandler> object to update the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.InTemplateMode%2A> value when the template mode changes for the associated control. Custom designers that are derived from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.TemplatedControlDesigner> class can override the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.TemplatedControlDesigner.OnTemplateModeChanged%2A> method to perform additional processing when the template editing mode changes for a control in the design host.

Docs.summary: Invalidates the whole area of the control that is displayed on the design surface and signals the control designer to redraw the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks To enable the control designer to handle paint events, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetViewFlags%2A> method in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.Initialize%2A> method.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.Invalidate%2A> method provides the design host with a way to instruct the control designer to redraw the control. Essentially, this is the same as calling <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UpdateDesignTimeHtml%2A> method, because it causes the whole control to be redrawn.

remarks.format:
## Remarks To enable the control designer to handle paint events, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetViewFlags%2A> method in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.Initialize%2A> method.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.Invalidate%2A> method provides the design host with a way to instruct the control designer to redraw a specific part of the control.

.method public static hidebysig void InvokeTransactedChange(class System.ComponentModel.IComponent component, class System.Web.UI.Design.TransactedChangeCallback callback, object context, string description) cil managed
Public Shared Sub InvokeTransactedChange (component As IComponent, callback As TransactedChangeCallback, context As Object, description As String)

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.param: The control associated with the control designer.
A object representing a function to call in the control designer as part of the transaction.
An object that contains the argument for callback.

Docs.summary: Wraps a series of changes into a transaction, using the specified parameters that can be rolled back as a unit with the undo functionality of the design host.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The implementation of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.InvokeTransactedChange%2A> method notifies the design host, which is determined by the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.Site%2A> property of `component`, that a change is occurring in the associated control and, if the change is not canceled by the design host, invokes the specified `callback` using the specified `context`, and then notifies the design host that the change has completed.
If the design host or the associated control throws a static `Canceled` exception field of a <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.CheckoutException> exception, the transaction is canceled without invoking `callback`.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to create a simple composite control with a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Label> and a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TextBox> control, together with properties to set the label text, and also the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TextBox.Text%2A>, <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.Width%2A>, and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.BackColor%2A> properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TextBox> control. An associated control designer class creates three <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionMethodItem> commands, each of which sets two properties on the control. By using the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.InvokeTransactedChange%2A> method, you can use the undo functionality of the design host, such as [!INCLUDE[vsprvslong](~/includes/vsprvslong-md.md)], to roll back each completed transaction as a unit.
[!code-csharp[DesignerInvokeTransactedChange#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/DesignerInvokeTransactedChange/CS/InvokeTransactedChangeSample.cs#1)] [!code-vb[DesignerInvokeTransactedChange#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/DesignerInvokeTransactedChange/VB/InvokeTransactedChangeSample.vb#1)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks The implementation of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.InvokeTransactedChange%2A> method notifies the design host, which is determined by the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.Site%2A> property of `component`, that a change is occurring to the specified `member` (property or method) of the associated control and, if the change is not canceled by the design host, invokes the specified `callback` using the specified `context` as the argument, and then notifies the design host that the change has completed.
If the design host or associated control throws a static `Canceled` exception field of a <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.CheckoutException> exception, the transaction is canceled without invoking `callback`.

Docs.summary: Called by the design host when the user clicks the associated control at design time.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.IControlDesignerView.ViewEvent> event is raised by the design host for certain actions on a control in the design surface. For example, an event is raised for the following conditions:
- The user clicks the control.
- The control designer paints on the design surface.
- The user enters or exits template editing mode for the control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class supplies a default delegate to handle the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.IControlDesignerView.ViewEvent?displayProperty=nameWithType> event. Classes deriving from <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> override the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnClick%2A> method to process events that are raised when the user clicks a control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnClick%2A> method allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
The default implementation of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnClick%2A> method returns without performing any processing.
## Examples The following code example shows how to use a handler for the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnClick%2A> event in a clickable region of the control and use a <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegionMouseEventArgs> object to identify the region that is being clicked.
This code example is part of a larger code example for the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.EditableDesignerRegion> class.
[!code-csharp[SimpleMultiRegionControlDesigner#4](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/SimpleMultiRegionControlDesigner/CS/SimpleMultiRegionControlDesigner.cs#4)] [!code-vb[SimpleMultiRegionControlDesigner#4](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/SimpleMultiRegionControlDesigner/VB/SimpleMultiRegionControlDesigner.vb#4)]

block.para: Override the method in a class deriving from the class to handle design-time click events on the control. If is not null, the clicked region, if any, is specified in the property.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnComponentChanged%2A> method is called when a property on the associated control is changed. It allows the implementer to do any processing that might be required after a property change. Calling the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnComponentChanged%2A> method causes the design host to call the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method. The base implementation of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnComponentChanged%2A> method also persists the control in the page markup.

block.para:
Override the method to provide additional processing before persisting the control and before refreshing the design-time HTML markup.
When overriding the method in a derived class, make sure that you call the method for the base class so that registered delegates receive the event.

remarks.format:
## Remarks
> [!NOTE] > The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnControlResize%2A> method is obsolete. Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnComponentChanged%2A> method for equivalent control designer functionality.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnControlResize%2A> method typically is called only by the design-time environment when a user action causes the associated Web server control to be resized. The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnControlResize%2A> method might be called several times during a resizing process to display the updated size of the control before the resizing is completed. The width and height properties of the control are updated before the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnControlResize%2A> method is called.

Docs.summary: Called when the control designer draws the associated control on the design surface, if the value is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.IControlDesignerView.ViewEvent> event is raised by the design host for certain actions on a control in the design surface. For example, an event is raised for the following conditions:
- The user clicks the control.
- The design host requests HTML markup to render the associated control on the design surface.
- The user enters or exits template editing mode for the control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class supplies a default delegate to handle the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.IControlDesignerView.ViewEvent?displayProperty=nameWithType> event. Classes deriving from <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> should set the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ViewFlags.CustomPaint?displayProperty=nameWithType> value and override the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnPaint%2A> method to process events that are raised when the design host draws the control on the design surface.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnPaint%2A> method allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
The default implementation of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnPaint%2A> method returns without performing any processing.

block.para: Override the method in a class deriving from the class to handle paint events for a control in the design surface. However, the event occurs only if the value has been set with the method.

Docs.summary: Adds properties to or removes properties from the Properties grid in a design host at design time or provides new design-time properties that might correspond to properties on the associated control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks With the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.PreFilterProperties%2A> method, you can add items to the dictionary of properties that a control designer exposes through a <xref:System.ComponentModel.TypeDescriptor> object.
The keys in the dictionary of properties are the names of the properties. The objects are of type <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor>.

block.para: You can directly modify the dictionary that is accessible through the properties parameter, or you can leave it unchanged. If you override the method, call the base implementation before you perform your own filtering.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class is read-only, by nature. Read/write features are provided by adding a <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion> object or using base classes, such as the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ContainerControlDesigner> class.
> [!NOTE] > The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ReadOnly%2A> property is obsolete. Derive from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ContainerControlDesigner> class to which you can add editable designer regions or from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.TemplatedControlDesigner> object to which you can create editable designer regions in templates.

MemberSignature.Value: public void RegisterClone (object original, object clone);
.method public hidebysig instance void RegisterClone(object original, object clone) cil managed
Public Sub RegisterClone (original As Object, clone As Object)
public: void RegisterClone(System::Object ^ original, System::Object ^ clone);

Docs.param: The control associated with the control designer.
The cloned copy of the associated control.
Docs.summary: Registers internal data in a cloned control.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Whenever an item is cloned, there might be some internal data structures, such as `meta:` attributes, that should be included in the cloned control by the control designer. A page developer might add `meta:` attributes to the markup of a control and there is no way, nor is there a reason, for the control to distinguish what those tags might be. Therefore, if your control designer provides a way to edit complex properties or formats before applying changes to a page, you would create a clone of the control, pass both the original control and the clone to this <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.RegisterClone%2A> method, and then, when the changes are persisted to the tag, all `meta:` attributes are also persisted.

## Remarks Classes deriving from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class can support region-based editing on the design surface and override the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetEditableDesignerRegionContent%2A> method to set the content for a specified region.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Normally, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetRegionContent%2A> method is not overridden in derived designers. The base class causes the design host to call the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetEditableDesignerRegionContent%2A> method for the region. Override the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetRegionContent%2A> method when custom data is required for the control before calling <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetEditableDesignerRegionContent%2A> method.
Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetRegionContent%2A> method to insert HTML markup into a region of the control.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void UpdateDesignTimeHtml() cil managed
abstract member UpdateDesignTimeHtml : unit -> unit override this.UpdateDesignTimeHtml : unit -> unit

Docs.summary: Refreshes the design-time HTML markup for the associated Web server control by calling the method.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UpdateDesignTimeHtml%2A> method is called by the design host to update the display of the associated Web server control at design time, such as when the control has been modified. Also, a control designer can call the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UpdateDesignTimeHtml%2A> method after modifying values of the control to update the display of the control.
> [!NOTE] > If you are calling the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.IComponentChangeService.ComponentChanged> event, or using the <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor> object to set properties, the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.IComponentChangeService> interface calls the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UpdateDesignTimeHtml%2A> method for you.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to respond to a `Click` event in a control designer to change the focus between regions in a multi-region control and use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UpdateDesignTimeHtml%2A> method to update the appearance of the control in the design host.
This code example is part of a larger example for the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.EditableDesignerRegion> class.
[!code-csharp[SimpleMultiRegionControlDesigner#4](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/SimpleMultiRegionControlDesigner/CS/SimpleMultiRegionControlDesigner.cs#4)] [!code-vb[SimpleMultiRegionControlDesigner#4](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/SimpleMultiRegionControlDesigner/VB/SimpleMultiRegionControlDesigner.vb#4)]

MemberSignature.Value: Protected Overridable ReadOnly Property UsePreviewControl As Boolean
protected: virtual property bool UsePreviewControl { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the control designer uses a temporary preview control to generate the design-time HTML markup.
Docs.value: , if the control designer uses a temporary copy of the control for design-time preview; otherwise, , if the control designer uses the property for the control contained in the control designer.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UsePreviewControl%2A> property is `true`, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ViewControl%2A> property returns a temporary copy of the control. Changes to the temporary control are not persisted to the document.
If the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UsePreviewControl%2A> property is `false`, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ViewControl%2A> property returns an instance of the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentDesigner.Component%2A> property for the control. Changes to the instance of the control are persisted.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute.SupportsPreviewControl%2A> setting in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute> object is used to set the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UsePreviewControl%2A> property. Therefore, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute.SupportsPreviewControl%2A> setting determines the type of control that is returned by the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ViewControl%2A> property in the base <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class. If the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute> is not specified in the control designer declaration, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> object behavior is equivalent to specifying the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute.SupportsPreviewControl%2A> property as `false`.

block.para: Custom designers that are derived from the class can override the property and ignore the object. Generally, to indicate that the property always returns a temporary copy of the control, override the property to always return . To indicate that the property always returns an instance of the control, override the property to always return . For example, the class derives from the and always returns for the property.

member this.ViewControl : System.Web.UI.Control with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a Web server control that can be used for previewing the design-time HTML markup.
Docs.value: A object used by the base class to generate design-time HTML markup.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ViewControl%2A> property uses the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UsePreviewControl%2A> property to determine its return value.
If the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UsePreviewControl%2A> property is `true`, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ViewControl%2A> property returns a temporary copy of the control. Changes to the temporary control are not persisted.
If the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UsePreviewControl%2A> property is `false`, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ViewControl%2A> property returns an instance of the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentDesigner.Component%2A> property for the control. Changes to the instance of the control are persisted.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute.SupportsPreviewControl%2A> setting in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute> object is used to set the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UsePreviewControl%2A> property. Therefore, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute.SupportsPreviewControl%2A> setting determines the type of control that is returned by the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ViewControl%2A> property in the base <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class. If the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute> is not specified in the control designer declaration, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> object behavior is equivalent to specifying the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute.SupportsPreviewControl%2A> property as `false`.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to mark a control designer with the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute> attribute. The code example derives a Web server control from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Label> class and associates the control with a custom control designer implementation. The control designer class declaration is marked with the `SupportsPreviewControl` attribute set to `true`. The control designer overrides the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method, and then displays the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Label.Text%2A> property of the control in italic at design time.
[!code-csharp[System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute/CS/supportspreviewdesigner.cs#1)] [!code-vb[System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute/VB/supportspreviewdesigner.vb#1)]
